ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Repair of corrupted ARC files
ygData.msgSnippet: If the damage occurs *after* you ve created the access-index of the record offsets in the ARC file (the index IA has traditionally called a CDX ), then only

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Repair of corrupted ARC files
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=qa7T8cB9BpluphEIT7-1LWu6fEXalUvs3YM8wgngpQ9a
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

If the damage occurs *after* you've created the access-index of the 
record offsets in the ARC file (the index IA has traditionally called a 
'CDX'), then only accessing the record or records in the damaged range 
would hit errors.

I presume instead you're trying to index files after the damage. We'd 
like to make our tools more robust; can you say anything more about the 
damage, and what versions of the indexing tools you're using, and how 
exactly they fail? (Is the entire ARC left out, or just the portion 
after the corruption?)

That said, holding tools constant, the most straightforward strategy if 
you believe the corruption to be of a limited range of the file is 
probably to:

(1) Identify the last uncorrupted record. Create one new ARC that is 
only through that record.

(2) From the end of the last good record, search through the file for 
the distinctive byte pattern that accompanies the beginning of a GZIP 
member -- hex 0x1F8B -- and each place it appears, try treating the 
remainder of the file for successful indexing with your tools. (Each 
ARC/WARC record begins a new independent GZIP member.)

(3) For the first such point that succeeds, create a second new ARC that 
is the original ARC from that point forward.

It's not a guarantee that all 0x1F8B occurences start GZIP ranges, but 
that pattern gives a limited number of candidate points to try for 
interpreting the tail of the file.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA


eleonora_nicchiarelli wrote:
> Dear all, 
> 
> We are archiving arc.gz files created by Heritrix through the Netarchive Suite. We have strong reasons to believe that one of our files has been corrupted on the disk (its size is only ~19 MB, and it is not possible to unzip it conventionally). 
> 
> Now we would like to "extend" the file to a valid arc.gz file so that it is possible to view its contents through e.g. wayback all the same (which is not possible at the moment). Is there a standard way to do this? 
> 
> Thanks in advance, 
> 
> Eleonora
